items.title: Method controls whether freezing droplets bounce off or stick
items.summary: Self-peeling droplets have been discovered, along with a new way to control adhesion of freezing droplets by adjusting the thermal properties of substrates. These findings could make everything from additive manufacturing to deicing more efficient.

alternate.title: Method controls whether freezing droplets bounce off or stick

thumbnail.title: Method controls whether freezing droplets bounce off or stick

items.title: Why your ancestors would have aced the long jump
items.summary: A 52-million-year-old ankle fossil suggests our prehuman ancestors were high-flying acrobats. For years, scientists thought the ancestors of today's humans, monkeys, lemurs and apes were relatively slow and deliberate animals, using their grasping hands and feet to creep along small twigs and branches. But a new study suggests the first primates were masters at leaping through the trees.

alternate.title: Why your ancestors would have aced the long jump

thumbnail.title: Why your ancestors would have aced the long jump

items.title: A new genetic marker for schizophrenia
items.summary: Scientists find a rare genetic variant that shows strong association with schizophrenia.

alternate.title: A new genetic marker for schizophrenia

items.title: The turbulent healing powers of plasma
items.summary: Non-equilibrium atmospheric pressure plasma can help heal wounds, destroy cancer cells and kill harmful bacteria. The jets of plasma that doctors might use, however, often become turbulent with the direction and velocity changing dramatically. Now, researchers have found this turbulence likely emerges from heat-induced sound waves generated at the plasma electrodes. This new insight is critical for more consistent and effective medical therapies.

alternate.title: The turbulent healing powers of plasma

items.title: A novel and practical fab-route for superomniphobic liquid-free surfaces
items.summary: Scientists have developed a fabrication technology that can inexpensively produce surfaces capable of repelling liquids, including water and oil.

alternate.title: A novel and practical fab-route for superomniphobic liquid-free surfaces

thumbnail.title: A novel and practical fab-route for superomniphobic liquid-free surfaces

items.title: Connecting up the quantum internet
items.summary: Major leap for practical building blocks of a quantum internet: New research demonstrates how to dramatically improve the storage time of a telecom-compatible quantum memory, a vital component of a global quantum network. The technology operates in the same 1550 nanometer band as today's telecommunications infrastructure. It can also be operated as a quantum light source or used as an optical link for solid-state quantum computing devices such as superconducting qubits and silicon qubits.

items.title: Cooperation driven by reciprocity, not conformity
items.summary: From an evolutionary perspective, cooperating with others can yield benefits that increase chances of survival. But what are the conditions that motivate us to cooperate? New research suggests that reciprocity -- cooperation under the assumption that we will receive benefits in return -- outweighs our desire to conform with group norms when we're deciding whether to cooperate with someone.

alternate.title: Cooperation driven by reciprocity, not conformity

items.title: New treatment option discovered for brain injury patients suffering from aggression
items.summary: A drug originally developed in the 1960s as an antiviral medication is showing promise as a treatment option for people who suffer from increased feelings of aggression following traumatic brain injury, researchers have reported.

alternate.title: New treatment option discovered for brain injury patients suffering from aggression
